sen.j: 藤原懐平の二男として生まれるが、時期は不明ながら、懐平の弟でその祖父藤原実頼の養子となっていた、実資の養子となる。
sen.e: He was born as the second son of FUJIWARA no Kanehira, but later he became an adopted child of FUJIWARA no Sanesuke, who was Kanehira's little brother and was adopted by his grandfather FUJIWARA no Sanoyori.

sen.j: 実資は実頼の家系（小野宮流）の嫡流となっていたため、資平は三歳上の実兄の藤原経通と並んで官途を昇ることとなった。
sen.e: As Sanesuke was adopted as the main line of the family of Saneyori (Ononomiya Line), Sukehira was also benefitted to move up the promotional ladder as a government officer together with his elder brother by blood, FUJIWARA no Tsunemichi.

sen.j: 長徳3年（997年）に、12歳で従五位下の叙位を受け、翌年には侍従に任官し、その後も養父の引き上げもあり、順調に官位を昇進し、長和4年には公卿に次ぐ蔵人頭に任官する。
sen.e: In 997, he was conferred Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) at the age of 12, and the next year he was appointed to jiju (chamberlain), and afterwards he continued his advancement to higher official rank, and he took the post of Kurodo no to (head chamberlain), the second position after Kugyo (the top court officials), in 998.

sen.j: 当時の三条天皇は、廟堂の首班である藤原道長とは疎遠であり、その関係から天皇は実資を相談相手とすることが多く、資平の蔵人頭も道長との押し問答のようなやり取りの挙句に、天皇が強行したものだった。
sen.e: As Emperor Sanjom was estranged, at that time, from FUJIWARA no Michinaga who presided the imperial court, tended to count on Sanesuke as an adviser, and at the occasion of Sukehira's promotion to Kurodo no to, the Emperor forced through his decision after having a vigorous argument with Michinaga.

sen.j: この時期は、三条天皇の眼病が進行し、その退位が予想されていた時期でもあったため、天皇に近侍する蔵人頭の職であった資平も、重大な場面に立ち会うこともあった。
sen.e: During this period, because of Emperor Sanjo's worsening eye trouble, his abdication was anticipated, and therefore, Sukehira, who closely served the Emperor as Kurodo no to, sometimes witnessed important situations.

sen.j: 実資の日記「小右記」によると、長和4年（1015年）4月29日 (旧暦)には、資平の見たこととして、道長が三条天皇に退位を要求したが天皇は断ったことをうかがわせる一文が記されている。
sen.e: In his diary, "Shoyuki" (the diary of FUJIWARA noSanesuke), Sanesuke wrote an episode on May 25, 1015 (April 29 in old lunar calendar), by referring to a scene witnessed by Sukehira, to suggests that although Michinaga demanded Emperor Sanjo's abdication, the Emperor refused.

sen.j: 三条天皇の退位で後一条天皇が即位すると、長和6年（1017年）には、参議に任官し公卿となった。
sen.e: After Emperor Goichijo ascended the throne, following Emperor Sanjo's abdication, Sukehira was appointed to Sangi (councilor) and became one of Kugyo (top court officials).

sen.e: However it seems that he continued conducting his duties in relation with Emperor Sanjo, and when the Emperor's Chugu (the second consort of the Emperor) FUJIWARA no Kenshi became Empress Dowager, he closely serve her as Kotaigogu gon no daibu (provisional master of the Empress Dowager's Household).

sen.e: Since he became Gon Chunagon (provisional vice-councilor of state) in 1029, he served in the Imperial Court for more than 30 years in the same official position, until he was appointed to Gon Dainagon (provisional chief councilor of state).

sen.e: During that period, Sanesuke, who was the Minister of the Right, died in 1046, and in continuation, Tsunemichi also died in 1051, and gradually Sukehira came to be obliged to assume a heavy responsibility as the legitimate line of the main line of the Ononomiya Line

sen.e: His first son, Sukefusa, became Sangi, and his elder brother's sons, Tsunesue and Akiie, also became Sangi successively, however, he was hit by a tragedy that Sukefusa died in 1057 leaving him behind.

sen.j: しかし、資平自身は長寿で、藤原頼通が子の藤原師実を内大臣に引き上げるため、太政大臣に移った際の異動で、76歳にして権大納言となり、さらに4年後の康平8年（1065年）には大納言に昇った。
sen.e: On the other hand, he lived long, and when there was a personnel relocation followed by the FUJIWARA no Yorimichi's transfer to the Grand Minister, in which Yorimichi moved over with the intention to let his own son, FUJIWARA no Morozane be the Minister of the Interior, Sukehira became Gon Dainagon (provisional chief councilor of state), and four years later, in 1065, he was raised to Dainagon (chief councilor of state).

sen.j: 天喜元年（1053年）の伊賀国で本家の威光を背景に、税を納めない荘園の立券を停止することを命じている官宣旨では、藤原教通、藤原能信、藤原信長らの、道長の子孫（御堂流）と並んで、資平の荘園も挙げられている。
sen.e: There was a Kan-senshi (an edict from Dajokan (Grand Council of State) which had the status of a binding official document) issued in 1053 in Iga Province, and it ordered to discontinued issuing the certificates to shoen (manors in medieval Japan), which admitted shoen's exemption from paying the tax backed by the authority of Honke (the owner of the highest-graded patches of land under the stratified land ruling structure of Shoen), and Sukehira's shoen was subject to this edict, as well as, those of the Michinaga's descendents (Mido Line), such as FUJIWARA no Norimichi, FUJIWARA no Yoshinobu, and FUJIWARA no Nobunaga.
